Literature Review: Insulin clearance plays a crucial role in maintaining glucose homeostasis and has gained increasing attention in recent years as a potential contributor to the pathogenesis of various metabolic disorders. This literature review aims to explore the current understanding of insulin clearance in health and disease, with a focus on its implications for insulin resistance, obesity, hepatic steatosis, and type 2 diabetes.Insulin clearance is a complex process that involves the removal of insulin from circulation through receptor-mediated endocytosis and subsequent degradation. The liver is the primary site of insulin clearance, accounting for approximately 60-80% of total insulin removal, while extrahepatic tissues contribute to a lesser extent. Recent studies have shed light on the molecular mechanisms underlying insulin clearance, particularly the role of the membrane glycoprotein CEACAM1 (carcinoembryonic antigen-related cell adhesion molecule 1) in hepatic insulin clearance.Poy et al. (2002) demonstrated that CEACAM1 plays a critical role in promoting receptor-mediated insulin uptake and degradation in hepatocytes. Their study using transgenic mice with liver-specific inactivation of CEACAM1 showed impaired insulin clearance and the development of insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and hepatic steatosis. This groundbreaking work established CEACAM1 as a key regulator of insulin clearance and highlighted its potential involvement in metabolic disorders.Subsequent research has further elucidated the relationship between insulin clearance and various metabolic conditions. Lee et al. (2013) conducted a large-scale genome-wide association study that identified genetic variants associated with reduced insulin clearance in diverse populations. Their findings suggested that impaired insulin clearance may be a heritable trait and could contribute to the development of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes.The link between reduced insulin clearance and obesity has been extensively investigated. Kotronen et al. (2008) demonstrated that obese individuals exhibit decreased hepatic insulin clearance compared to lean subjects, independent of insulin sensitivity. This reduction in insulin clearance was associated with increased liver fat content, suggesting a potential mechanism by which obesity may lead to hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance.Age-related changes in insulin clearance have also been observed. Basu et al. (2006) reported that insulin clearance decreases with age, potentially contributing to the increased risk of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes in older adults. Their study highlighted the importance of considering age-related changes in insulin metabolism when assessing metabolic health.Ethnic differences in insulin clearance have been documented, providing insights into the varying prevalence of metabolic disorders among different populations. Haffner et al. (1986) found that Mexican Americans exhibited lower insulin clearance rates compared to non-Hispanic whites, which may partially explain the higher prevalence of type 2 diabetes in this ethnic group.The relationship between insulin clearance and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has garnered significant attention. Kotronen et al. (2007) demonstrated that patients with NAFLD have reduced hepatic insulin clearance, which correlates with the degree of liver fat accumulation. This finding suggests that impaired insulin clearance may be both a consequence and a contributor to the development of hepatic steatosis.Recent research has also explored the potential therapeutic implications of targeting insulin clearance. Russo et al. (2017) investigated the effects of metformin, a widely used antidiabetic drug, on insulin clearance in patients with type 2 diabetes. They found that metformin treatment improved insulin clearance, suggesting that modulation of insulin clearance may be a viable therapeutic strategy for managing metabolic disorders.The interplay between insulin clearance and insulin secretion in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes has been a subject of ongoing research. Bergman et al. (2019) proposed a model in which reduced insulin clearance initially serves as a compensatory mechanism to maintain normal glucose levels in the face of insulin resistance. However, prolonged hyperinsulinemia may eventually lead to β-cell dysfunction and the development of type 2 diabetes.In conclusion, the growing body of evidence suggests that reduced insulin clearance plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of various metabolic disorders, including insulin resistance, obesity, hepatic steatosis, and type 2 diabetes. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying insulin clearance, such as the role of CEACAM1, and the factors influencing its regulation, including age, ethnicity, and liver fat content, may provide new avenues for therapeutic interventions. Future research should focus on elucidating the complex interplay between insulin clearance, insulin secretion, and insulin sensitivity to develop more targeted and effective treatments for metabolic disorders.
